body: @sijie Oops..It seems to have to support c++ client as the same time to pass the unit tests. I will fix it later.

```

11:20:50.975 [ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-2] INFO  org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.ServerCnx - [/172.17.0.1:46854] Created new producer: Producer{topic=PersistentTopic{topic=persistent://public/default/my-topic}, client=/172.17.0.1:46854, producerName=standalone-5-4, producerId=0}
11:20:51.133 [pulsar-io-49-1] INFO  org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.ServerCnx - [PersistentTopic{topic=persistent://public/default/my-topic}][standalone-5-4] Closing producer on cnx /172.17.0.1:46854
11:20:51.134 [pulsar-io-49-1] INFO  org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.ServerCnx - [PersistentTopic{topic=persistent://public/default/my-topic}][standalone-5-4] Closed producer on cnx /172.17.0.1:46854
```

But when I pull it into my larger project it just hands with the following broker logs:
```
11:22:54.293 [pulsar-io-49-3] INFO  org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.ServerCnx - New connection from /172.17.0.1:47080
11:23:07.940 [pulsar-web-55-3] INFO  org.eclipse.jetty.server.RequestLog - 127.0.0.1 - - [19/May/2019:11:23:07 +0000] "GET /admin/v2/persistent/public/functions/coordinate/stats HTTP/1.1" 200 776 "-" "Pulsar-Java-v2.3.1" 2
11:23:24.293 [pulsar-io-49-3] WARN  org.apache.pulsar.common.api.PulsarHandler - [[id: 0x08270021, L:/172.17.0.2:6650 - R:/172.17.0.1:47080]] Pulsar Handshake was not completed within timeout, closing connection
11:23:24.294 [pulsar-io-49-3] INFO  org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.ServerCnx - Closed connection from /172.17.0.1:47080
```
Both the working test executable and the failed larger project executable have the same go module graphs for puslar:
```
$ go mod graph | grep pulsar | sort 
github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go@v0.0.0-20190507044647-1f4a836a4648
github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go@v0.0.0-20190507044647-1f4a836a4648 github.com/BurntSushi/toml@v0.3.1
github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go@v0.0.0-20190507044647-1f4a836a4648 github.com/sirupsen/logrus@v1.3.0
github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go@v0.0.0-20190507044647-1f4a836a4648 github.com/stretchr/testify@v1.3.0
github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go@v0.0.0-20190507044647-1f4a836a4648 gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack.v2@v2.0.0
github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go@v0.0.0-20190507044647-1f4a836a4648 gopkg.in/yaml.v2@v2.2.2
```
Ah Ha!!!! I figured it out.  I was creating a producer in an init() function and apparently that just hangs forever.

I think, this issue has to do with CreateProducer() depending on multiple goroutines executing so it can write/read to a channel:
https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/6485ccf75d96f282c2c61e1dd87b85e42de64102/pulsar-client-go/pulsar/c_client.go#L207

But all Go init() functions execute in a single goroutine: https://golang.org/ref/mem#tmp_4
@ppgoml I think this was an issue that was fixed in master.

changed this issue from a bug to a feature. because originally we were planning to support deadletter topic for shared subscription only. If we are going to support it for exclusive and failover, it is a feature request here.

To summarize the problems here, 

a) in Java, you can use `withJsonDef` in SchemaDefinitionBuilder to enforce the avro schema. Hence I think your question in Java is answered, correct?

b) in Python, does python schema provides similar `withJsonDef` work for you as well?

@sijie @codelipenghui I think we should consider change it back to no ack-timeout and instead encourage using negativeAck. 

If an application has a processing logic that can (even occasionally) take >30s, this default setting will degrade very badly.

@liketic Seems the failed [tests](https://builds.apache.org/job/pulsar_precommit_java8/8990/) is related to this change:
```
[[FATAL] A resource model has ambiguous (sub-)resource method for HTTP method PUT and input mime-types as defined by"@Consumes" and "@Produces" annotations at Java methods public void org.apache.pulsar.broker.admin.v1.NonPersistentTopics.createPartitionedTopic(java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,int,boolean) and public void org.apache.pulsar.broker.admin.v1.PersistentTopics.createPartitionedTopic(java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,int) at matching regular expression /([^/]+)/([^/]+)/([^/]+)/([^/]+)/partitions. These two methods produces and consumes exactly the same mime-types and therefore their invocation as a resource methods will always fail.; source='org.glassfish.jersey.server.model.RuntimeResource@6690b9fa']
	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.ApplicationHandler.initialize(ApplicationHandler.java:394)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.ApplicationHandler.lambda$initialize$1(ApplicationHandler.java:316)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.Errors.process(Errors.java:316)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.Errors.process(Errors.java:298)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.Errors.processWithException(Errors.java:256)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.ApplicationHandler.initialize(ApplicationHandler.java:315)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.ApplicationHandler.<init>(ApplicationHandler.java:282)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.servlet.WebComponent.<init>(WebComponent.java:335)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.servlet.ServletContainer.init(ServletContainer.java:178)
	at org.glassfish.jersey.servlet.ServletContainer.init(ServletContainer.java:370)
	at javax.servlet.GenericServlet.init(GenericServlet.java:244)
	at org.eclipse.jetty.servlet.ServletHolder.initServlet(ServletHolder.java:670)
```
